title.value: Repeat it without me: Crowdsourcing the T 1 mapping common ground via the ISMRM reproducibility challenge
title.justification: It is the main title listed at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Repeat it without me: Crowdsourcing the T 1 mapping common ground via the ISMRM reproducibility challenge

extractions.description: The paper discusses a challenge launched by the ISMRM Reproducible Research and Quantitative MR study groups to assess the reproducibility of a well-established inversion-recovery T 1 mapping technique using a standardized phantom and human brains.

type.justification: The paper involves extensive data collection and analysis to assess reproducibility across multiple submissions and sites.
type.quote: Purpose: T 1 mapping is a widely used quantitative MRI technique, but its tissue-specific values remain inconsistent across protocols, sites, and vendors. The ISMRM Reproducible Research and Quantitative MR study groups jointly launched a challenge to assess the reproducibility of a well-established inversion-recovery T 1 mapping technique.

name.justification: The paper focuses on T 1 mapping and reproducibility within quantitative MRI, which is a subfield of medical imaging.
name.quote: Significant challenges exist in the reproducibility of quantitative MRI.

name.justification: The study specifically focuses on the reproducibility of MRI T 1 mapping techniques.
name.quote: Purpose: T 1 mapping is a widely used quantitative MRI technique.

name.justification: The paper emphasizes the reproducibility of T 1 mapping techniques, which is central to the study.
name.quote: This study reports the inherent uncertainty in T 1 measures across independent research groups.

name.justification: The study evaluates the reproducibility of the inversion-recovery T 1 mapping technique.
name.quote: The ISMRM Reproducible Research and Quantitative MR study groups jointly launched a challenge to assess the reproducibility of a well-established inversion-recovery T 1 mapping technique.

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not propose this as a new model, but evaluates its reproducibility across different centers.
is_contributed.quote: The ISMRM Reproducible Research and Quantitative MR study groups jointly launched a challenge to assess the reproducibility of a well-established inversion-recovery T 1 mapping technique.

is_executed.justification: The model was not executed in the conventional sense of a computational model; rather, its application was assessed across multiple sites.
is_executed.quote: The ISMRM Reproducible Research and Quantitative MR study groups jointly launched a challenge to assess the reproducibility of a well-established inversion-recovery T 1 mapping technique.

is_compared.justification: The study compared the T 1 mapping results from different submissions to evaluate reproducibility.
is_compared.quote: Intersubmission and intrasubmission comparisons were performed.

referenced_paper_title.value: A robust methodology for in vivo T 1 mapping.
referenced_paper_title.justification: Barral et al. (2010) is referenced as the seminal work from which the T 1 mapping protocol was derived.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Methods: The challenge used the acquisition protocol from Barral et al. (2010).

name.justification: The data was collected from this phantom to evaluate the reproducibility of T 1 mapping.
name.quote: Researchers collected T 1 mapping data on the ISMRM/NIST phantom and/or in human brains.

referenced_paper_title.value: A standard system phantom for magnetic resonance imaging
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper involves the usage of the ISMRM/NIST system phantom to gather data for assessment.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine (ISMRM) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) collaborated on a standard system phantom.

name.justification: Human brain data was explicitly collected and analyzed for T 1 mapping variability.
name.quote: The challenge explored whether the acquisition details in a seminal paper on T 1 mapping were sufficient to ensure the reproducibility across independent research groups.

referenced_paper_title.value: A robust methodology for in vivo T 1 mapping.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The human brain data was used to assess the reproducibility based on the Barral et al., 2010 protocol.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The challenge used the acquisition protocol from Barral et al. (2010).

name.justification: qMRLab was used as a tool for processing T 1 maps during the challenge.
name.quote: A Jupyter Notebook pipeline using qMRLab was used to process the T 1 maps and to conduct quality control checks.

referenced_paper_title.value: qMRLab: quantitative MRI analysis, under one umbrella
referenced_paper_title.justification: qMRLab's use in processing T 1 maps is a part of the paper's workflow documentation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A Jupyter Notebook pipeline using qMRLab was used to process the T 1 maps and to conduct quality control checks.
